Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Plate Boundary Observatory on the Nicoya Peninsula, Costa Rica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The work proposed is to augment, upgrade and extend the monitoring period of an existing network of GPS and seismic instrumentation on the Nicoya Peninsula, Costa Rica. The questions to be addressed by the data collected include: 1) What is the relationship between slow slip, tremor, strain accumulation and interplate earthquakes. 2) What is the role of temperature and fluids in tremor and slip generation? 3) Is the occurrence of fast and slow slip tremor spatially and/or temporally separated? The answers to these questions have important implications for understanding seismic processes at subduction zones.

Broader Impacts
This project includes the training of several Ph.D. students. It also includes technology and science transfer to Costa Rica to improve their monitoring of earthquakes. The PIs propose to travel to 2 minority institutions to recruit students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The plate boundary at convergent margins or subduction zones, produces most of the world’s largest earthquakes, threatening populations through destructive shaking and tsunami generation. Because of the significant societal impacts, it is important to understand the mechanisms controlling faulting behavior in this environment. However, the shallow earthquake-generating portion of subduction zones, called the megathrust, is difficult to characterize because it is relatively inaccessible tens of kilometers below the ocean in most locations. At the northern Costa Rica convergent boundary, the Nicoya Peninsula extends close to the trench, allowing optimum positioning of instruments over the megathrust. It is therefore an ideal location to implement a plate boundary observatory. We established a network of high precision, continuously recording GPS receivers and broadband seismometers on the Nicoya Peninsula to study faulting behavior. This network has been operating continuously from late 2008 through 2015.  On September 5, 2012 a magnitude 7.6 earthquake occurred beneath the Nicoya Peninsula and our network providing data to analyze the megathrust behavior before, during and after a large earthquake. Our results show that the region of the plate interface we determined to be locked prior to the earthquake became the loci of maximum coseismic slip. This strongly coupled patch was surrounded both up and down-dip by slow earthquakes indicating a separation in the mechanical properties of the seismogenic zone into strong patches that accumulate strain before and slip during large earthquakes and weaker regions that exhibit slow slip. This research underscores the importance of geodetic monitoring of megathrusts during the interseismic stage to identify regions most likely to slip in large future earthquakes. The project involved the career development of several graduate and undergraduate students and strengthened international collaboration between the US and Costa Rica.
